Randulpho and Benvoglio seem fearful, and seem to report to Angelina and Dorothea what hath passed before.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: This is your rashness, brother.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O joy, thou wert too great to last;
This was a cruel turning to our hopes,
Unnatural father: poor Ascanio.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O mother, let me be Gerrard again,
And follow Violanta.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O my son —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your lives yet, bloody men, shall answer this,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I must not see 'em longer grieve. My lord,
Be comforted; let sadness generally
Forsake each eye and bosom; they both live:
For poison, I infused mere opium;
Holding compulsive perjury less sin
Than such a loathed murder would have been.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O blessed maiden.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Music, gently creep
Into their ears, and fright hence lazy sleep.
Morpheus, command thy servant sleep
In leaden chains no longer keep
This prince and lady: rise, wake, rise,
And round about convey your eyes:
Rise prince, go greet thy father and thy mother;
Rise thou to embrace thy husband and thy brother.

sp.speaker: Du. Cor.
sp.l: Son, daughter.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Father, mother, brother.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Wife,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Are we not all in heaven?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I'faith, very near it.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: How can this be?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hear it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If I had served you right, I should have seen
Your old pate off, ere I had revealed.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: O wench,
O honest wench; if my wife die, I'll marry thee:
There's my reward.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Tis very strange.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Why kneel you, honest master?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: My good lord.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Dear mother.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Rise, rise, all are friends: I owe ye
For all their boards: and wench, take thou the man
Whose life thou savedst; less cannot pay thy merit.
How shall I part my kiss? I cannot: let
One generally therefore join our cheeks.
A pen of iron, and a leaf of brass,
To keep this story to eternity:
And a Promethean wit. O sacred love,
Nor chance, nor death can thy firm truth remove.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now Isabella. Flourish.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: This can true love do.
I joy they all so happily are pleased:
The ladies and the brothers must triumph.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: They do:
For Cupid scorns but to have his triumph too.

div.stage: Enter divers musicians, then certain singers bearing bannerets inscribed, truth, loyalty, patience, Concord: next Gerrard and Ferdinand with garlands of roses: then Violanta: last a chariot drawn by two Cupids, and a Cupid sitting in it. Flourish.

sp.l: Love, and the strength of fair affection
(Most royal sir) what long seemed lost have won
Their perfect ends, and crowned those constant hearts
With lasting triumph, whose most virtuous parts,
Worthy desires, and love, shall never end.
Now turn we round the scene, and (Great sir) lend
A sad and serious eye to this of death,
This black and dismal triumph; where man's breath,
Desert, and guilty blood ascend the stage,
And view the tyrant ruined in his rage. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: No, good my lord, I am not now to find
Your long neglect of me; all those affections
You came first clad in to my love, like summer,
Lusty and full of life: all those desires
That like the painted spring bloomed round about ye,
Giving the happy promise of an harvest,
How have I seen drop off, and fall forgotten?
With the least lustre of another's beauty,
How oft (Forgetful lord) have I been blasted?
Was I so easily won? or did this body
Yield to your false embraces with less labour
Than if you had carried some strong town?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Good Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Could all your subtleties and sighs betray me,
The vows ye shook me with, the tears ye drowned me,
Till I came fairly off with honoured marriage?
O fie, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Prithee, good Gabriella.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Would I had never known ye, nor your honours,
They are stuck too full of griefs: o happy women,
That plant your love in equal honest bosoms,
Whose sweet desires, like roses set together,
Make one another happy in their blushes,
Growing and dying without sense of greatness,
To which I am a slave! and that blessed sacrament
That daily makes millions of happy mothers,
Linked me to this man's lust alone, there left me.
I dare not say I am his wife, 'tis dangerous:
His love, I cannot say: alas, how many?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: You grow too warm; pray ye be content, you best know
The time's necessity, and how our marriage
Being so much unequal to mine honour,
While the Duke lives, I standing high in favour;
And whilst I keep that safe, next to the dukedom,
Must not be known, without my utter ruin.
Have patience for a while, and do but dream wench,
The glory of a Duchess. How she tires me?
How dull and leaden is my appetite
To that stale beauty now? O, I could curse
And crucify myself for childish doting
Upon a face that feeds not with fresh figures
Every fresh hour: she is now a surfeit to me.
Who's that? Gentle? I charge ye, no acquaintance
You nor your maid with him, nor no discourse
Till times are riper.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Fie, my noble lord,
Can you be now a stranger to the court,
When your most virtuous bride, the beauteous Helena
Stands ready like a star to gild your happiness,
When Hymen's lusty fires are now a lighting,
And all the flower of Anjoy?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Some few trifles,
For matter of adornment, have a little
Made me so slow, gentle, which now in readiness,
I am for court immediately.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Take heed, sir,
This is no time for trifling, nor she no lady
To be now entertained with toys: 'twill cost ye —

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: You're an old cock, gentle.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: By your lordship's favour.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Prithee away; 'twill lose time.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O my lord,
Pardon me that by all means.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: We have business
Afoot man of more moment.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Then my manners?
I know none, nor I seek none.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Take tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Even now, by your lordship's leave. Excellent beauty,
My ever service here I dedicate,
In honour of my best friend, your dead father,
To you his living virtue, and wish heartily,
That firm affection that made us two happy,
May take as deep undying root, and flourish
Betwixt my daughter Casta, and your goodness,
Who shall be still your servant.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I much thank ye.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: — of this dreaming puppy. Will ye go, sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A little more, good lord.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Not now, by —
Come, I must use ye.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Goodness dwell still with you. Exeunt Gentille and Lavall.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: The sight of this old gentleman, Maria,
Pulls to mine eyes again the living picture
Of perolot his virtuous son, my first love,
That died at Orleans.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You have felt both fortunes,
And in extremes, poor lady: for young perolot,
Being every way unable to maintain you,
Durst not make known his love to friend or father:
My lord Lavall, being powerful, and you poor,
Will not acknowledge you.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: No more: let's in wench:
There let my lute speak my laments; they have tired me.

sp.speaker: 1. courtier
sp.l: I grant, the Duke is wondrous provident
In his now planting for succession,
I know his care as honourable in the choice too,
Marine's fair virtuous daughter: but what's all this?
To what end excellent arrives this travel,
When he that bears the main roof is so rotten?

sp.speaker: 2. Cou.
sp.l: You have hit it now indeed: for if fame lie not,
He is untemperate.

sp.speaker: 1. courtier
sp.l: You express him poorly,
Too gentle sir: the most deboist and barbarous;
Believe it, the most void of all humanity,
Howe'er his cunning cloak it to his uncle,
And those his pride depends upon.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: I have heard too,
Given excessively to drink.

sp.speaker: 1. courtier
sp.l: Most certain,
And in that drink most dangerous: I speak these things
To one I know loves truth, and dares not wrong her.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: You may speak on.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Uncertain as the sea, sir,
Proud and deceitful as his sins great master;
His appetite to women, for there he carries
His main sail spread so boundless and abominably,
That but to have her name by that tongue spoken,
Poisons the virtue of the purest virgin.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: I am sorry for young Gabriella then,
A maid reputed ever of fair carriage,
For he has been noted visiting.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: She is gone then,
Or any else, that promises or power,
Gifts, or his guileful vows can work upon;
But these are but poor parcels.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: 'Tis great pity.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Nor want these sins a chief saint to befriend 'em,
The devil follows him; and for a truth sir,
Appears in visible figure often to him,
At which time he is possessed with sudden trances,
Cold deadly sweats, and griping of the conscience,
Tormented strangely as they say.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: Heaven turn him:
This marriage day mayst thou well curse, fair Helen.
But let's go view the ceremony.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: I'll walk with you. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Gabriella and Maria above. And Lavall, bride, states in solemnity as to marriage; and pass over; viz. Duke, Marine, Longavile.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I hear 'em come.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.l: Would I might never hear more.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I told you still: but you were so incredulous.
See, there they kiss.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Adders be your embraces.
The poison of a rotten heart, oh Helen,
Blast thee as I have been; just such a flattery,
With that same cunning face, that smile upon 't,
Oh mark it Marry, mark it seriously,
That master smile caught me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There's the old Duke, and
Marine her father.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There Longavile —
The ladies now.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: O, I am murdered, marry.
Beast, most inconstant beast.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: There I am not;
No more I am not there: hear me o heaven,
And all you powers of justice bow down to me;
But you of pity die. I am abused,
She that depended on your providence,
She is abused: your honour is abused,
That noble piece ye made, and called it man,
Is turned to devil: all the world is abused:
Give me a woman's will provoked to mischief,
A two edged heart; my suffring thoughts to wild-fires,
And my embraces to a timeless grave turn.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here I'll step in, for 'tis an act of merit.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I am too big to utter more.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Take time then.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This solitary life at home undoes thee,
Obscures thy beauty first, which should prefer thee;
Next fills thee full of sad thoughts, which thy years
Must not arrive at yet, they choke thy sweetness:
Follow the time, my girl, and it will bring thee
Even to the fellowship of the noblest women,
Helen herself, to whom I would prefer thee,
And under whom this poor and private carriage
Which I am only able yet to reach at,
Being cast off, and all thy sweets at lustre,
Will take thee as a fair friend, and prefer thee.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Good sir, be not so cruel as to seek
To kill that sweet content y' have bred me to:
Have I not here enough to thank heaven for?
The free air uncorrupted with new flattery,
The water that I touch unbribed with odours
To make me sweet to others: the pure fire
Not smothered up, and choked with lustful incense
To make my blood sweat; but burning clear and high,
Tells me my mind must flame up so to heaven.
What should I do at court, wear rich apparel?
Methinks these are as warm: and for your state, sir,
Wealthy enough; is it you would have me proud,
And like a pageant, stuck up for amazements?
Teach not your child to tread that path, for fear (Sir)
Your dry bones after death, groan in your grave
The miseries that follow.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Excellent Casta.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: When shall I pray again (A courtier)?
Or when I do, to what God? what new body
And new face must I make me, with new manners?
For I must be no more myself. Whose mistress
Must I be first? with whose sin-offering seasoned?
And when I am grown so great and glorious
With prostitution of my burning beauties,
That great lords kneel, and princes beg for favours,
Do you think I'll be your daughter, a poor gentleman's,
Or know you for my father?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My best Casta,Enter Lavall.
O my most virtuous child, heaven reigns within thee;
Take thine own choice, sweet child, and live a saint still.
The lord Lavall; stand by, wench.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Gabriella,
She cannot, nor she dares not make it known,
My greatness crushes her, whene'er she offers:
Why should I fear her then?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come, let's pass on wench.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Gentle, come hither: who's that gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A child of mine, sir, who observing custom,
Is going to the monastery to her prayers.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: A fair one, a most sweet one; fitter far
To beautify a court, then make a votarist.
Go on, fair beauty, and in your orisons
Remember me: will ye, fair sweet?

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Most humbly. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: An admirable beauty: how it fires me!
But she's too full of grace, and I too wicked.
I feel my wonted fit: defend me, goodness.
O, it grows colder still, and stiffer on me,
My hair stands up, my sinews shake and shrink:
Help me good heaven, and good thoughts dwell within me.
O get thee gone, thou evil evil spirit;
Haunt me no more, I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: Yes Lavall:
Thou art my vassal, and the slave to mischief,
I blast thee with new sin: pursue thy pleasure;
Casta is rare and sweet, a blowing beauty;
Set thy desires afire, and never quench 'em
Till thou enjoyest her; make her all thy heaven,
And all thy joy, for she is all true happiness:
Thou art powerful, use command; if that prevail not,
Force her; I'll be thy friend.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O help me, help me.

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.p: Her virtue, like a spell, sink me to darkness. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: He's here still. How is 't, noble lord? methinks , sir,
You look a little wildly. Is it that way?
Is't her you stare on so? I have spied your fire, sir,
But dare not stay the flaming. Come.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Sweet creature,
Excellent beauty, do me but the happiness
To be your humblest servant. O fair eyes,
Oh blessed, blessed sweetness, divine virgin.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: O good my lord, retire into your honour:
You're spoken good and virtuous, placed at helm
To govern others from mischances: from example
Of such fair chronicles as great ones are,
We do, or sure we should direct our lives.
I know you're full of worth, a school of virtue
Daily instructing us that live below ye,
I make no doubt, dwells there.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I cannot answer,
She has struck me dumb with wonder.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Goodness guide ye. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: She's gone, and with her all light, and has left me
Dark as my black desires. O devil lust,
How dost thou hug my blood, and whisper to me,
There is no day again, no time, no living,
Without this lusty beauty break upon me?
Let me collect myself, I strive like billows,
Beaten against a rock, and fall a fool still.
I must enjoy her, and I will: from this hour
My thoughts and all my business shall be nothing,
My eating, and my sleeping, but her beauty,
And how to work it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Health to my lord Lavall.
Nay good sir, do not turn with such displeasure;
I come not to afflict your new born pleasures;
My honoured mistress, neither let that vex ye,
For nothing is intended but safe to you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: What of your mistress? I am full of business.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will be short, my lord; she, loving lady,
Considering the unequal tie between ye,
And how your ruin with the Duke lay on it,
As also the most noble match now made,
By me sends back all links of marriage,
All holy vows, and rights of ceremony,
All promises, oaths, tears, and all such pawns
You left in hostage: only her love she cannot,
For that still follows ye, but not to hurt ye;
And still beholds ye sir, but not to shame ye:
In recompense of which, this is her suit, sir,
Her poor and last petition, but to grant her,
When weary nights have cloyed ye up with kisses,
(As such must come) the honour of a mistress,
The honour but to let her see those eyes,
(Those eyes she dotes on more than gods do goodness)
And but to kiss ye only: with this prayer,
(A prayer only to awake your pity)
And on her knees she made it; that this night
You'ld bless her with your company at supper.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I like this well, and now I think on't better,
I'll make a present use from this occasion:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, good my lord, be not so cruel to her because she has been yours.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: And to mine own end
A rare way I will work.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Can love for ever,
The love of her (My lord) so perish in ye?
As ye desire in your desires to prosper.
What gallant under heaven, but Anjou's heir then
Can brag so fair a wife, and sweet a mistress?
Good noble lord.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ye misapply me, marry,
Nor do I want true pity to your lady:
Pity and love tell me, too much I have wronged her
To dare to see her more: yet if her sweetness
Can entertain a mediation,
And it must be a great one that can cure me;
My love again, as far as honour bids me,
My service and myself.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's nobly spoken.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Shall hourly see her; want shall never know her;
Nor where she has bestowed her love, repent her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now whither drives he?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I have heard, Maria,
That no two women in the world more loved,
Than thy good mistress, and gentiles fair daughter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What may this mean? You have heard a truth, my lord:
But since the secret love betwixt you two,
My mistress durst not entertain such friendship;
Casta is quick, and of a piercing judgement,
And quickly will find out a flaw.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Hold Marry:
Shrink not, 'tis good gold, wench: prepare a banquet,
And get that Casta thither; for she's a creature
So full of forcible divine persuasion,
And so unwearied ever with good office,
And she shall cure my ill cause to my mistress,
And make all errors up.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll do my best sir:
But she's too fearful, coy, and scrupulous,
To leave her father's house so late; and bashful
At any man's appearance, that I fear sir,
'Twill prove impossible.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: There's more gold, Marry,
And fain thy mistress wondrous sick to death, wench.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have ye in the wind now, and I'll pay ye.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: She cannot choose but come; 'tis charity,
The chief of her profession: undertake this,
And I am there at night; if not, I leave ye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will not lose this offer, though it fall out
Clean cross to that we cast. I'll undertake it,
I will, my lord; she shall be there.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: By —?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By — she shall.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Let it be something late then,
For being seen. Now force or favour wins her.
My spirits are grown dull, strong wine, and store,
Shall set 'em up again, and make me fit
To draw home at the enterprise I aim at. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Go thy ways, false lord, if thou holdest, thou payest
The price of all thy lusts. Thou shalt be three,
Thou modest maid, if I have any working,
And yet thy honour safe; for which this thief
I know has set this meeting: but I'll watch him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Are mine eyes mine own? or bless me,
Am I deluded with a flying shadow?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why do your start so from me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It speaks sensibly,
And shows a living body: yet I am fearful.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Give me your hand, good Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He feels warm too.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And next your lips.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He kisses perfectly.
Nay, and the devil be no worse: you are perolot.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I was, and sure I should be: can a small distance,
And ten short months take from your memory
The figure of your friend, that you stand wondering?
Be not amazed, I am the selfsame perolot,
Living, and well; son to gentle, and brother
To virtuous Casta; to your beauteous mistress,
The long since poor betrothed, and still vowed servant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, sure he lives. My lord Lavall, your master,
Brought news long since to your much mourning mistress,
Ye died at Orleans; bound her with an oath too,
To keep it secret from your aged father,
Lest it should rack his heart.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A pretty secret
To try my mistress love, and make my welcome
From travel of more worth; from whence, heaven thanked,
My business for the Duke dispatched to th' purpose,
And all my money spent, I am come home, wench.
How does my mistress? for I have not yet seen
Any, nor will I, till I do her service.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But did the lord Lavall know of your love, sir,
Before ye went?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yes: by much force he got it,
But none else knew; upon his promise too
And honour to conceal it faithfully
Till my return; to further which, he told me,
My business being ended, from the Duke
He would procure a pension for my service,
Able to make my mistress a fit husband.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But are you sure of this?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sure as my sight, wench.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then is your lord a base dissembling villain,
A devil lord, the damned lord of all lewdness,
And has betrayed ye 'And undone my mistress,
My poor sweet mistress: o that lecher lord,
Who, poor soul, since was married.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: To whom, Maria?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: To that unlucky lord, a — upon him;
Whose hot horse-appetite being allayed once
With her chaste joys, married again, scarce cooled,
The torches yet not out the yellow Hymen
Lighted about the bed, the songs yet sounding,
Marine's young noble daughter Helena,
Whose mischief stands at door next. O that recreant!

sp.speaker: Perolot.
sp.l: O villain! O most unmanly falsehood!
Nay then I see, my letters were betrayed too.
O, I am full of this, great with his mischiefs,
Loaden and burst: come lead me to my lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I cannot, sir, Lavall keeps her concealed.
Besides, her griefs are such, she will see no man.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I must and will go to her: I will see her:
There be my friend, or this shall be thy furthest.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hold, and I'll help ye: but first ye shall swear to me,
As you are true and gentle, as ye hate
This beastly and base lord, where I shall place ye,
(Which shall be within sight) till I discharge ye,
Whate'er you see or hear, to make no motion.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I do by —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay here about the house then,
Till it be later; yet the time's not perfect:
There at the backdoor I'll attend you truly.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: O monstrous, monstrous, beastly villain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How cross this falls, and from all expectation?
And what the end shall be, heaven only yet knows:
Only I wish, and hope. But I forget still,
Casta must be the bait, or all miscarries.

div.stage: Enter Gentille with a torch: Shaloon above.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Holla, Shaloon.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: A word from the Duke, sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Tell your lord he must to court straight.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: He is ill at ease, and prays he may be pardoned
The occasions of this night.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Belike, he is drunk then:
He must away; the Duke, and his fair lady,
The beauteous Helena, are now at cent;
Of whom she has such fortune in her carding,
The Duke has lost a thousand crowns, and swears,
He will not go to bed, till by lavall
The tide of loss be turned again. Awake him,
For 'tis the pleasure of the Duke he must rise.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Having so strict command (Sir) to the contrary,
I dare not do it: I beseech your pardon.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Are you sure he is there?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: And asleep?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I think so.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: And are you sure you will not tell him, Shalon?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Yes, very sure.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Then I am sure, I will.
Open, or I must force.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Pray ye stay: he is not,
Nor will not be this night. You may excuse it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I knew he was gone about some woman's labour.
As good a neighbour, though I say it, and as comfortable:
Many such more we need Shaloon. Alas, poor lady,
Thou art like to lie cross-legged tonight . Good monsieur,
I will excuse your master for this once, sir,
Because sometimes I have loved a wench myself too.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: 'Tis a good hearing sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But for your lie, Shaloon,
If I had you here, it should be no good hearing,
For your pate I would pummel.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: A fair good night, sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good night, thou noble knight, sir Pandarus.
My heart is cold o'th sudden, and a strange dulness
Possesses all my body: thy will be done heaven.

div.stage: Enter Gabriella and Casta: and Maria with a taper.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: I'faith friend, I was even going to my bed,
When your maid told me of your sudden sickness:
But from my grave (So truly I love you)
I think your name would raise me: ye look ill
Since last I saw ye, much decayed in colour:
Yet I thank heaven, I find no such great danger
As your maid frighted me withal: take courage
And give your sickness course: some grief you have got
That feeds within upon your tender spirits,
And wanting open way to vent itself
Murders your mind, and chokes up all your sweetness,

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: It was my maid's fault; worthy friend to trouble ye,
So late, upon so light a cause: yet sure I have ye
Oh my dear Casta.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Out with it god's name.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: The closet of my heart, I will lock here, wench,
And things shall make ye tremble. Who's that knocks there?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis lavall.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Sit you still. Let him in.
In am resolved, and all you wronged women,
You noble spirits, that as I have suffered
Under this glorious beast-insulting man,
Lend me your causes, than your cruelties,
For I must put on madness above women.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Why do you look so ghastly?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Peace; no harm, dear. Enter Lavall.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: There, take my cloak and sword: where is this banquet?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In the next room,

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: How came he here? Heaven bless me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Give me some wine wench; fill it full, and sprightly.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Sit still, and be not fearful.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Till my veins swell,
And my strong sinews stretch like that brave centaur
That at the table snatched the bride away
In spite of Hercules.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: I am betrayed.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Nay start not lady; 'tis for you that I come,
And for your beauty: 'tis for you, lavall
Honours this night; to you, the sacred shrine
I humbly bow, offering my vows and prayers;
To you I live.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: In with the powder quickly:
So, that and the wine will rock ye.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Here, to the health
Of the most beauteous and divine, fair Casta,
The star of sweetness.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Fear him not, I'll die first.
And who shall pledge ye?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Thou shalt, thou tanned Gipsy:
And worship to that brightness give, cold tartar.
By — ye shall not stir; ye are my mistress,
The glory of my love, the great adventure,
The mistress of my heart, and she my whore.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Thou liest, base, beastly lord; drunker than anger,
Thou soused lord, got by a surfeit, thou liest basely.
Nay, stir not; I dare tell thee so. Sit you still.
If I be whore, it is in marrying thee,
That art so absolute and full a villain,
No sacrament can save that piece tied to thee.
How often hast thou wooed in those flatteries,
Almost those very words, my constancy?
What goddess have I not been, or what goodness?
What star that is of any name in heaven,
Or brightness? which of all the virtues
(But drunkenness, and drabbing, thy two morals)
Have not I reached to? what spring was ever sweeter?
What Scythian snow so white? what crystal chaster?
Is not thy new wife now the same too? Hang thee,
Base bigamist, thou honour of ill women.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: How's this? O heaven defend me.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Thou salt-itch;
For whom no cure but ever burning brimstone
Can be imagined.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Dost thou laugh, thou breaker
Of all law, all religion, of all faith
Thou foul contemner?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Peace, thou paltry woman:
And sit by me, sweet.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: By the devil?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Come,
And lull me with delights.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: It works amain now.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Give me such kisses as the Queen of shadows
Gave to the sleeping boy she stole on Patmus;
Lock round about in snaky wreathes close folded,
Those rosy arms about my neck, oh Venus.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Fear not, I say.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Thou admirable sweetness,
Distil thy blessings like those silver drops,
That falling on fair grounds, rise all in roses:
Shoot me a thousand darts from those fair eyes,
And through my heart transfix 'em all, I'll stand 'em.
Send me a thousand smiles, and presently
I'll catch 'em in mine eyes, and by Love's power
Turn 'em to Cupid's all, and fling 'em on thee.
How high she looks, and heavenly! More wine for me.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.l: Give him more wine, and good friend be not fearful.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Here on my knee, thou goddess of delights,
This lusty grape I offer to thy beauties;
See how it leaps to view that perfect redness
That dwells upon thy lips: now, how it blushes
To be outblushed. O let me feed my fancy,
And as I hold the purple god in one hand
Dancing about the brim 'And proudly swelling,
Decked in the pride of nature young, and blowing;
So let me take fair Semele in the other,
And sing the loves of gods, then drink, their nectar's
Not yet desired.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Then like lusty Tarquin
Turned into flames with Lucrece coy denials,
His blood and spirit equally ambitious,
I force thee for mine own.

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: O help me, justice:
Help me, my chastity.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Now I am bravely quarried. Perolot above.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis my sister.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: No, bawdy slave, no treacher, she is not carried.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: She's loose again, and gone. I'll keep my place still.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now it works bravely: stand, he cannot hurt ye.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: O my sweet love, my life. He falls down, and sleeps.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He sinks.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: My blessing.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So, now he is safe a while.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Lock all the doors, wench,
Then for my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Now I'll appear to know all.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Be quick, quick, good Mary, sure and sudden.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Stay, I must in first.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: On my conscience
It is young Perolot: oh my stung conscience!
It is my first and noblest love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Leave wondering,
And recollect yourself: the man is living,
Equally wronged as you, and by that devil.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis most true, lady: your unhappy fortune
I grieve for as mine own, your fault forgive too,
If it be one. This is no time for kisses:
I have heard all, and known all, which mine ears
Are cracked apieces with, and my heart perished.
I saw him in your chamber, saw his fury,
And am afire till I have found his heart out.
What do you mean to do? for I'll make one.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: To make his death more horrid (For he shall die)

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: He must, he must.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: We'll watch him till he wakes,
Then bind him, and then torture him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing.
No, take him dead drunk now without repentance,
His lechery inseamed upon him.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'll do it myself; and when 'tis done, provide ye,
For we'll away for Italy this night.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: We'll follow thorough all hazards.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: O false lord,
Unmanly, mischievous; how I could curse thee.
But that but blasts thy fame; have at thy heart, fool:
Loopholes I'll make enough to let thy life out.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O, does the devil ride me?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Murder.
Nay, then take my share too.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Help; o, he has slain me.
Bloody intentions must have blood.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Heaven.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: He sinks, he sinks, for ever sinks: oh fortune!
O sorrow, how like seas thou flowest upon me!
Here will I dwell for ever. Weep, Maria,
Weep this young man's misfortune: oh thou truest.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: What have I done?

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: That that has marked thy soul man.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: And art thou come again, thou dismal spirit?

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: Yes, to devour thy last.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Mercy upon me.

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: Thy hour is come: succession, honour, pleasure,
And all the lustre thou so long hast looked for
Must here have end: summon thy sins before thee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O my affrighted soul!

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: There lies a black one;
Thy own best servant by thy own hand slain,
Thy drunkenness procured it: there's another,
Think of fair Gabriella, there she weeps;
And such tears are not lost.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O miserable!

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: Thy foul intention to the virtuous Casta.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: No more, no more, thou wildfire.

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: Last, thy last wife,
Think on the wrong she suffers.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O my misery,
O, whither shall I fly?

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: Thou hast no faith, fool.
Hark to thy knell. Sings, and vanishes.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Millions of sins muster about mine eyes now:
Murders, ambitions, lust, false faiths; oh horror,
In what a stormy form of death thou ridest now!
Methinks I see all tortures, fires, and frosts,
Deep sinking caves, where nothing but despair dwells,
The baleful birds of night hovering about 'em;
A grave, methinks , now opens, and a hearse
Hung with my arms tumbles into it: o,
O, my afflicted soul: I cannot pray;
And the least child that has but goddess in him
May strike my head off; so stupid are my powers:
I'll lift mine eyes up though.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Cease these laments,
They are too poor for vengeance: Lavall lives yet.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Then thus I dry all sorrows from these eyes,
Fury and rage possess 'em now: damned devil.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: This for young perolot.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O mercy, mercy.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: This for my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: But one short hour to cure me.
O be not cruel: o, o.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hark, they knock.
Make haste for heaven's sake, mistress.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: This for Casta.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O, oh, o, o. He dies.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He's dead: come quickly, let is away with him,
'T will be too late else.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Help, help up to th' chamber.

div.stage: Enter Duke, Helena, Gentile, Casta, and attendants, with lights.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What frights are these?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I am sure here's one passed frighting.
Bring the lights nearer: I have enough already.
Out, out, mine eyes. Look, Casta.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: 'T is young perolot.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: When came he over? Hold the gentlewoman,
She sinks; and bear her off.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O my dear brother! Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: There is a time for all; for me, I hope, too,
And very shortly. Murdered?

div.stage: Gabriella, Maria, with Lavall's body, above.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Who is above there?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Look up, and see.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What may this mean?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Behold it;
Behold the drunken murderer
Of that young gentleman; behold the rankest,
The vilest, basest slave that ever flourished.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Who killed him?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I; and there is the cause I did it:
Read, if your eyes will give you leave.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: O monstrous.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Nay, out it shall: there, take this false heart to ye,
The base dishonour of a thousand women:
Keep it in gold, Duke, 't is a precious jewel.
Now to myself; for I have lived a fair age,
Longer by some months then I had a mind to.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Here, young perolot; my first contracted
True love shall never go alone.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hold, Gabriella,
I do forgive all.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I shall die the better.
Thus let me seek my grave, and my shames with me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nor shalt thou go alone my noble mistress:
Why should I live, and thou dead?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Save the wench there.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: She is; I hope; and all my sins here written.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This was a fatal night.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Heaven has his working,
Which we cannot contend against.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Alas.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Your grace has your alas too.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Would 't were equal;
For thou hast lost an honest noble child.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'T is heir enough has lost a good remembrance.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: See all their bodies buried decently,
Though some deserved it not. How do you, lady?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Even with your grace's leave, ripe for a monastery;
There will I wed my life to tears and prayers,
And never know what man is more.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your pleasure;
How does the maid within?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: She is gone before, sir,
The same course that my lady takes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: And my course shall be my beads at home; so
Please your grace to give me leave to leave the court.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: In peace, sir,
And take my love along.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I shall pray for ye.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now to ourselves retire we, and begin
By this example to correct each sin. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: King. Em.
sp.l: By this we plainly view the two imposthumes
That choke a kingdom's welfare; ease, and wantonness;
In both of which Lavall was capital:
For first, ease stole away his mind from honour,
That active noble thoughts had kept still working,
And then delivered him to drink and women,
Lust and outrageous riot; and what their ends are,
How infamous and foul, we see example.
Therefore, that great man that will keep his name,
And gain his merit out of virtue's schools,
Must make the pleasures of the world his fools.

div.stage: Enter musicians: next them, Perolot with the wound he died with. Then Gabriella and Maria, with their wounds: after them, four furies with bannerets inscribed revenge, murder, lust and drunkenness, singing. Next them, Lavall wounded. Then a chariot with death, drawn by the destinies. Flourish.

sp.l: From this sad sight ascend your noble eye,
And see old time helping triumphantly
Helping his master man: view here his vanities,
And see his false friends like those glutted flies,
That when they have sucked their fill, fall off, and fade
From all remembrance of him, like a shade.
And last, view who relieves him; and that gone,
We hope your favour, and our play is done.

div.stage: Enter Anthropos, desire, and vain delight; bounty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What hast thou done, desire, and how employed
The charge I gave thee, about levying wealth
For our supplies?

sp.speaker: Desire.
sp.l: I have done all, yet nothing:
Tried all, and all my ways, yet all miscarried;
There dwells a sordid dulness in their minds.
Thou son of earth, colder than that thou art made of,
I came to craft, found all his hooks about him,
And all his nets baited and set; his sly self
And greedy lucre at a serious conference
Which way to tie the world within their statutes a
Business of all sides and of all sorts swarming
Like bees broke loose in summer: I declared
Your will and want together, both enforcing
With all the power and pains I had, to reach him;
Yet all fell short.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: His answer.

sp.speaker: Desire.
sp.l: This he gave me.
Your wants are never ending; and those supplies
That came to stop those breaches, are ever lavished
Before they reach the main, in toys and trifles,
Gewgaws, and gilded puppets: vain delight
He says has ruined ye, with clapping all
That comes in for support, on clothes, and coaches,
Perfumes, and powdered pates; and that your mistress,
The lady pleasure, like a sea devours
At length both you and him too. If you have houses,
Or land, or jewels, for good pawn, he'll hear you,
And will be ready to supply occasions;
If not, he locks his ears up, and grows stupid.
From him, I went to vanity ▪ whom I found
Attended by an endless troop of tailors,
Mercers, embroiderers, feather-makers, fumers,
All occupations opening like a mart,
That serve to rig the body out with bravery;
And through the room new fashions flew like flies,
In thousand gaudy shapes; pride waiting on her,
And busily surveying all the breaches
Time and delaying nature had wrought in her,
Which still with art she pieced again, and strengthened:
I told your wants; she showed me gowns and head-tires,
Embroidered waistcoats, smocks seamed thorough with cut-works,
Scarves, mantles, petticoats, muffs, powders, paintings,
Dogs, monkeys, parrots, which all seemed to show me
The way her money went. From her to pleasure
I took my journey.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: And what says our best mistress?

sp.speaker: Desire.
sp.l: She danced me out this answer presently:
Revels and masques had drawn her dry already.
I met old time too, mowing mankind down,
Who says you are too hot, and he must purge ye.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: A cold quietus. Miserable creatures,
Born to support and beautify your master,
The godlike man, set here to do me service,
The children of my will; why, or how dare ye,
Created to my use alone, disgrace me?
Beast's have more courtesy; they live about me,
Offering their warm wool to the shearers hand,
To clothe me with their bodies to my labours;
Nay, even their lives they daily sacrifice,
And proudly press with garlands to the altars,
To fill the gods oblations. Birds bow to me,
Striking their downy sails to do me service,
Their sweet airs ever echoing to mine honour,
And to my rest their plumy softs they send me.
Fishes, and plants, and all where life inhabits,
But mine own cursed kind, obey their ruler;
Mine have forgotten me, miserable mine,
Into whose stony hearts, neglect of duty,
Squint-eyed deceit, and self-love, are crept closely:
None feel my wants, not one mend with me.

sp.speaker: Desire.
sp.l: None, sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou hast forgotten (Desire) thy best friend, flattery;
He cannot fail me.

sp.speaker: Delight.
sp.l: Fail? he will sell himself,
And all within his power, close to his skin first.

sp.speaker: Desire.
sp.l: I thought so too, and made him my first venture,
But found him in a young lords ear so busy,
So like a smiling shower pouring his soul
In at his portals, his face in thousand figures
Catching the vain mind of the man: I pulled him,
But still he hung like birdlime; spoke unto him,
His answer still was, by the lord, sweet lord,
And by my soul, thou masterpiece of honour;
Nothing could stave him off: he has heard your flood's gone;
And on decaying things he seldom smiles, sir.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Then here I break up state, and free my followers,
Putting my fortune now to time, and justice:
Go seek new masters now; for Anthropos
Neglected by his friends, must seek new fortunes.
Desire, to avarice I here commend thee,
Where thou mayest live at full bent of thy wishes:
And vain delight, thou feeder of my follies
With light fantasticness, be thou in favour.
To leave thee, bounty, my most worthy servant,
Troubles me more than mine own misery;
But we must part: go plant thyself, my best friend,
In honourable hearts that truly know thee,
And there live ever like thyself, a virtue:
But leave this place, and seek the country
For law; and lust like fire lick all up here.
Now none but poverty, must follow me,
Despised patched poverty; and we two married,
Will seek simplicity, content and peace out,
And live with them in exile. How uncalled on
My true friend comes!

sp.speaker: Poverty.
sp.l: Here, hold thee, Anthropos,
Thou art almost armed at rest; put this on,
A penitential robe, to purge thy pleasures:
Off with that vanity.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Here, vain delight,
And with this all my part, to thee again
Of thee I freely render.

sp.speaker: Poverty
sp.l: Take this staff now,
And be more constant to your steps hereafter:
The staff is staidness of affections.
Away, you painted flies, that with man's summer
Take life and heat buzzing about his blossoms;
When growing full, ye turn to caterpillars,
Gnawing the root that gave you life. Fly shadows.
Now to content I'll give thee, Anthropos,
To rest and peace: no vanity dwells there;
Desire nor pleasure, to delude thy mind more;
No flatteries smooth-filed tongue shall poison thee.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: O Jupiter, if I have ever offered
Upon thy burning altars but one sacrifice
Thou and thy fair-eyed Juno smiled upon;
If ever, to thine honour, bounteous feasts,
Where all thy statues sweat with wine and incense,
Have by the son of earth been celebrated:
Hear me (The child of shame now) hear, thou helper,
And take my wrongs into thy hands, thou justice,
Done by unmindful man, unmerciful,
Against his master done, against thy order;
And raise again, thou father of all honour,
The poor despised, but yet thy noblest creature.
Raise from his ruins once more this sunk cedar,
That all may fear thy power, and I proclaim it.

div.stage: Jupiter and Mercury descend severally. Trumpets small above.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Hoa; Mercury, my winged son.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Your servant.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Whose powerful prayers were those that reached our ears,
Armed in such spells of pity now?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The sad petitions
Of the scorned son of earth, the godlike Anthropos,
He that has swelled your sacred fires with incense,
And piled upon your altars thousand heifers;
He that (Beguiled by vanity and pleasure,
Desire, craft, flattery, and smooth hypocrisy)
Stands now despised and ruined, left to poverty.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: It must not be; he was not raised for ruin;
Nor shall those hands heaved at mine altars perish:
He is our noblest creature. Flee to time,
And charge him presently release the bands
Of poverty and want this suitor sinks in:
Tell him, among the sunburnt Indians,
That know no other wealth but peace and pleasure,
She shall find golden Plutus, god of riches,
Who idly is adored, the innocent people
Not knowing yet what power and weight he carries:
Bid him compel him to his right use, honour,
And presently to live with Anthropos.
It is our will. Away.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I do obey it.

div.stage: Music. Enter Plutus, with a troop of Indians singing and dancing wildly about him, and bowing to him: which ended, enter time.

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: Rise, and away; 't is Jove's command.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: I will not:
Ye have some fool to furnish now; some Midas
That to no purpose I must choke with riches.
Who must I go to?

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: To the son of earth;
He wants the god of wealth.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: Let him want still:
I was too lately with him, almost torn
Into ten thousand pieces by his followers:
I could not sleep, but craft or vanity
Were filing off my fingers; not eat, for fear
Pleasure would cast herself into my belly,
And there surprise my heart.

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: These have forsaken him:
Make haste then; thou must with me: be not angry,
For fear a greater anger light upon thee.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: I do obey then: but change my figure;
For when I willingly befriend a creature,
Goodly and full of glory I show to him;
But when I am compelled, old, and decrepit,
I halt, and hang upon my staff. Fare well, friends,
I will not be long from ye; all my servants
I leave among ye still, and my chief riches.
O time, what innocence dwells here, what goodness!
They know me not, nor hurt me not, yet hug me.
Away, I'll follow thee: but not too fast, time.

div.stage: Enter Anthropos, honesty, simplicity, humility, poverty.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Man, be not sad, nor let this divorce
From Mundus, and his many ways of pleasure,
Afflict thy spirits; which considered rightly
With inward eyes, makes thee arrive at happy.

sp.speaker: Poverty
sp.l: For now what danger or deceit can reach thee?
What matter left for craft or covetise
To plot against thee? what desire to burn thee?

sp.speaker: Honesty
sp.l: O son of earth, let honesty possess thee;
Be as thou wast intended, like thy maker;
See thorough those gawdy shadows, that like dreams
Have dwelled upon thee long: call up thy goodness,
Thy mind and man within thee, that lie shipwrecked,
And then how thin and vain these fond affections,
How lame this worldly love, how lumplike raw
And ill-digested all these vanities
Will show, let reason tell thee,

sp.speaker: Simplicity
sp.l: Crown thy mind
With that above the world's wealth, joyful suffering,
And truly be the master of thyself,
Which is the noblest empire; and there stand
The thing thou wert ordained, and set to govern.

sp.speaker: Poverty
sp.p: Come, let us sing the world's shame: hear us, Anthropos.

div.stage: Song: and then enter time and Plutus.

sp.speaker: Honesty
sp.l: Away; we are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: Get thou too after,
Thou needy bare companion; go for ever,
For ever, I conjure thee: make no answer.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: What mak'st thou here, time? thou that to this
Minute never stood'st still by me?

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: I have brought thee succour;
And now catch hold, I am thine: the god of riches
(Compelled by him that saw thy miseries,
The ever just and wakeful Jove, at length)
Is come unto thee: use him as thine own;
For 't is the doom of heaven: he must obey thee.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Have I found pity then?

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: Thou hast; and justice
Against those false seducers of thine honour:
Come, give him present helps.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: Come, industry,
Thou friend of life: and next to thee, rise labour;
Rise presently: and now to your employments;
But first conduct this mortal to the rock.
sp.stage: They carry Anthropos to a rock, and fall a digging.
sp.l: What seest thou now?

div.stage: Plutus strikes the rock, and flames fly out.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: A glorious mine of metal.
O Jupiter, my thanks.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: To me a little.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: And to the god of wealth my sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: Nay, than I am rewarded. Take heed now, son,
You are afloat again, lest Mundus catch ye.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Never betray me more.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: I must to India,
From whence I came, where my main wealth lies buried,
And these must with me. Take that book and mattock,
And by those know to live again.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I shall do.

sp.speaker: Fame.
sp.l: Thorough all the world the fortune of great Anthr.
Be known and wondered at; his riches envied
As far as sun or time is; his power feared too.

div.stage: Music. Enter delight, pleasure, craft, Lucre, Vanity, etc. dancing (And masked) towards the rock, offering service to Anthropos. Mercury from above. Music heard. One half of a cloud drawn. Singers are discovered: then the other half drawn. Jupiter seen in glory.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Take heed, weak man, those are the sins that sunk thee:
Trust 'em no more: kneel, and give thanks to Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: O mighty power!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Unmask, ye gilded poisons:
Now look upon 'em, son of earth, and shame 'em;
Now see the faces of thy evil angels,
Lead 'em to time, and let 'em fill his triumph:
Their memories be here forgotten for ever.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: O just great god! how many lives of service,
What ages only given to thine honour,
What infinites of vows and holy prayers,
Can pay my thanks?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Rise up: and to assure thee
That never more thou shalt feel want, strike, Mercury,
Strike him; and by that stroke he shall for ever
Live in that rock of gold, and still enjoy it.
Be done, I say. Now sing in honour of him.

div.stage: First the musicians: then vain delight, pleasure, craft, Lucre, Vanity, and other of the vices: then a chariot with the person of time sitting in it; drawn by four persons representing hours, singing.

sp.speaker: King. Em.
sp.l: By this we note (Sweet heart) in Kings and princes
A weakness, even in spite of all their wisdoms,
And often to be mastered by abuses:
Our natures here described too, and what humours
Prevail above our reasons to undo us.
But this the last and best, when no friend stands,
The gods are merciful, and lend their hands.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: Now as the husbandman, whose costs and pain,
Whose hopes and helps lie buried in his grain,
Waiting a happy spring, to ripen full
His longed-for harvest to the reapers pull;
Stand we expecting, having sown our ground
With so much charge (The fruitfulness not found)
The harvest of our labours: for we know
You are our spring; and when you smile, we grow.
Nor charge nor pain shall bind us from your pleasures,
So you but lend your hands to fill our measures.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
